bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Harry J. Warthen, November 20, 1951

div1.p: Hench suggests a list of Reed items, which can be used for a Walter Reed Exhibit during the next meeting of the History of Medicine Section of the Richmond Academy of Science.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Harry J. Warthen, November 20, 1951
div1.opener:
November 20, 1951
Dr. Harry J. Warthen, Chairman
Section of History of Medicine
Richmond Academy of Medicine
1200 East Clay Street
Richmond 19, Virginia
My dear Doctor Warthen:
div1.p:
I have your request to help in the matter of a Walter Reed Exhibit on
the occasion of the Walter Reed Night to be held by the Section on the
History of Medicine next February.

The relatives of Walter Reed, Jesse Lazear and many of their associates
in the conquest of yellow fever have made me the custodian of a great
mass of original material which is being carefully preserved and which I
have carefully filed. The most valuable of this material - the original
letters of Walter Reed to his wife over a period of many years, including
the Cuban years, and those of Lazear to his family, also Walter Reed's
diplomas and other items are kept in a safe in my home. Unfortunately
at the moment, these data are somewhat “unavailable.” This summer we made
extensive improvements to our house, during which time a lot of extra
furniture and other material had to be stored in the same room in which
my yellow fever files reside. Because of the press of recent work, I
have not been able to clear up this room but hope to do it within the
next two or three months.

Meanwhile, I shall be glad to correspond with you further about the
exhibit. Because so much of what the Reed family and others have given
me is completely irreplaceable and invaluable, I have hesitated greatly to
lend any of it out. Indeed I have declined all such requests except one,
made a few years ago by the Association of Military Surgeons in connection
with a Walter Reed Memorial and in this case the exhibit was taken by me
to Washington and brought home by me and during the time of the exhibit it
was under constant supervision by military and association personnel. I
fear, therefore, that until these various items are framed, each in its
own protective case, the originals should not be loaned out, but I should
be glad to lend you copies of some of these originals, the most interesting
ones. Among them are such items as the following which I shall number for
the sake of convenience in our further correspondence.

list.item: 1. A photographic copy of Walter Reed's original Army commission.

2. Photostatic copy of Reed's application for commission in the Army, in-
cluding a biographical sketch of himself written in his own hand.
3. Photographs of his birthplace, before and after renovation.

4. Various photographs (or copies of photographs) of Walter Reed from
childhood on up, including one or two unpublished ones.

5. A selection of photostats or photographs, about a half dozen, of the
most important letters of those which Reed sent to his wife during the
yellow fever experiments, including photographs of his famous New Year's
Eve letter to his wife.

6. Photostats of one of the long-lost laboratory notebooks started by
Lazear, concluded by Reed, with notes concerning the yellow fever experi-
ments.

7. Photographs of various buildings of Camp Columbia, Cuba, where the
pre-Camp Lazear studies were made.
8. Copies of the old Army photographs of Camp Lazear taken in 1900.

9. Many original photographs which I took of Camp Lazear as we re-discovered
it in 1940; in particular, many photographs inside and outside the remains
of Reed's Building No. 1 which we re-discovered in 1940.

11. Photographs of all of Reed's diplomas, earned and honorary, from various
universities and hospitals.

div1.p:
This will give you an idea of the material that I have and if you think those
photographs or photostats would serve your purpose about as well as the
originals, I should be glad to cooperate in every way possible.

For ten years I have been trying to enlist the help of interested persons
in what I considered to be an important and worthwhile historic project.
In the November 4 issue of the New York Times appeared a little article on
my project. How it happened to be published there and then I do not know.
As a result, I have just had some correspondence with Mr. Frederick L. Rath, Jr.
Director of the National Trust for Historic Preservation. I enclose a copy
of the letter I have just sent to him. Do you think it would be possible for
the Historical Section of the Richmond Academy of Medicine to help in this
project in any way? I have been trying for so long to preserve the building
on the basis of my own individual efforts but so far have failed for reasons
given in the enclosed letter. I do think that we may succeed if the proper
association is made. The Walter Reed Memorial Association is willing to be the
sponsoring organization but needs badly the help of others. If you think that
your organization would be interested, I should be glad to send you, in the
near future, details about the plan, photographs of Camp Lazear and the
little building, (taken a couple of years ago when I was there last) and
diagrams and descriptions of the little memorial building that I had planned.
In the meantime, permit me to send you the enclosed four reprints which I hope
will interest you and may I call your attention in particular to the detailed
description of the re-discovery of the lost Camp Lazear as described on pages
3 to 7 of my reprint, “Walter Reed and the Conquest of Yellow Fever,” which
appeared in The Pharos, May 1948.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
